author: By Matt Stevens
title: Can I Go to See This Show? Must I Wear a Mask? It Depends.
description: Vaccination and mask requirements vary by venue. It’s a weird pandemic summer for the performing arts.
content: During its preview performances in June, New York Classical Theater was allowed to put on “King Lear” for only up to 75 audience members outdoors. Those patrons were socially distanced on picnic blankets, wore masks and could not eat or drink during the play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Gloria Richardson, Uncompromising Civil Rights Advocate, Dies at 99
description: Her efforts to refocus the movement on economic justice made her a bridge between more moderate leaders and Black Power activism.
content: Gloria Richardson, whose work as a civil rights leader on the Eastern Shore of Maryland in the early 1960s served as a bridge between the nonviolent activism of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the more radical, confrontational tactics and agendas of the Black Power movement that followed in the second half of the decade, died on July 15 at her home in Manhattan. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Merkel Visits Flood Region as Toll Continues to Mount
description: The chancellor met with those who lost their homes and with rescue teams and German Army troops searching for survivors, as the number of dead rose above 180 in Europe.
content: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel on Sunday met with survivors and thanked volunteers as she made her way through a village wrecked by the extraordinary floods that have killed at least 183 people in Germany and Belgium, calling the level of destruction “surreal and eerie.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ‘Historical Distortions’ Test South Korea’s Commitment to Free Speech
description: Conspiracy theories about the country’s turbulent past have spread online. Now the government is pushing criminal penalties to crack down on misinformation.
content: SEOUL — In the history of South Korea’s fight for democracy, the 1980 uprising in Gwangju stands out as one of the proudest moments. Thousands of ordinary citizens took to the streets to protest a military dictatorship, and hundreds were shot down by security forces. The bloody incident has been sanctified in textbooks as the “Gwangju Democratization Movement.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: ‘They Just Left Us’: Greece Is Accused of Setting Migrants Adrift at Sea
description: Frustrated by more than a year of picking up people they say Greece has illegally pushed out, Turkish officials invited journalists to witness rescues firsthand.
content: ABOARD A TURKISH COAST GUARD VESSEL — Wet and shaken, women and children were pulled aboard the Turkish patrol boat first, then the men and more children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Tadej Pogacar Claims Second Straight Tour de France Title
description: A dominant month produced an unassailable lead for Slovenia’s young champion in a cycling race shadowed by new cheating claims.
content: Tadej Pogacar of Slovenia won his second straight Tour de France on Sunday, entering a new era of dominance after reigning over his adversaries for nearly two weeks and leaving little room for any serious competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Neighbor Helping Neighbor, German Volunteers Lead Flood Recovery
description: ‘‘The cleanup will be a few weeks,’’ one said. But it will take months to check buildings and bridges to make sure they are sound, and many will have to be destroyed.
content: ALTENAHR, Germany — The volunteers were out in force on Sunday, with friends and neighbors of those afflicted by Germany’s catastrophic floods joined by members of the Technisches Helfswerke — the Federal Agency for Technical Relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Steal and Alley-Oop Leave Bucks One Win From an N.B.A. Title
description: Jrue Holiday’s daring decisions sealed a victory for Milwaukee in Game 5, giving the Bucks a 3-2 series lead over the Phoenix Suns.
content: PHOENIX — In the most consequential sequence of his basketball career, Jrue Holiday threw both caution and the basketball to the wind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson Finds Himself in a Quandary Over Racism and Sports
description: The British prime minister is under fire for failing to condemn crowds who booed when England’s soccer players took a knee during the European Championship.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain has labored to distance himself from Donald J. Trump since the change of power in Washington, and not without success. His first face-to-face meeting with President Biden last month went smoothly: The two found common ground on climate change and Mr. Johnson labeled Mr. Trump’s successor a “big breath of fresh air.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was 10 Blocks Into My Walk When I Saw a Tall Man Striding South’
description: A mysterious, elegant man, a quick cut and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Inflation, Billionaires in Space and Other Things Going Up
description: Prices are rising. China's economy is still growing, but at a slower pace. And airline travel is back.
content: The government reported that a key measure of inflation in June climbed at its fastest pace in 13 years, casting some doubt on the White House’s claim that postpandemic price increases are “transitory.” The inflation spike is clearly linked to the economy’s rapid reopening, which has created supply and demand mismatches. But there’s debate over how long it will remain elevated: Will it be temporary, as most policymakers believe, or stick around? On Wednesday, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, acknowledged that inflation had increased “notably” and said it was likely to remain high for six months or so. Still, the Fed is not expected to raise interest rates anytime soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Historically Black Colleges Finally Get the Spotlight
description: There are star hirings and hundreds of millions in donations. But not every institution is sharing in the bounty, and some are struggling to survive.
content: Historically Black colleges and universities are having a moment, one that many educators say is more than a century overdue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Klobuchar Lays Out New Goals for Often Low-Key Rules Committee
description: The panel typically focuses on the Senate’s inner workings, but its chairwoman, Amy Klobuchar, is seeking to transform it into a major force on voting rights.
content: WASHINGTON — The usually obscure Senate Rules Committee is the most insider of insider panels, typically responsible for doling out precious Capitol office space, keeping the Senate running and handling fights over arcane floor procedures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Michael Crowley
title: U.S. Habit of Backing Strongman Allies Fed Turmoil in Haiti
description: Washington dismissed warnings that democracy was unraveling under President Jovenel Moïse, leaving a gaping leadership void after his assassination.
content: As protesters hurled rocks outside Haiti’s national palace and set fires on the streets to demand President Jovenel Moïse’s resignation, President Trump invited him to Mar-a-Lago in 2019, posing cheerfully with him in one of the club’s ornate entryways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: How to Explain the Rise and Fall of WeWork?
description: In “The Cult of We,” Eliot Brown and Maureen Farrell examine how WeWork’s Adam Neumann built a billion-dollar company simply out of renting communal work space.
content: THE CULT OF WEWeWork, Adam Neumann, and the Great Startup DelusionBy Eliot Brown and Maureen Farrell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Born of a Crisis, Remote Voting in Congress Has Become a Useful Perk
description: An emergency measure intended to allow Congress to function amid a nationwide lockdown has become a matter of personal and political convenience for House members of both parties.
content: WASHINGTON — When the House revamped its rules in the early days of the pandemic to allow lawmakers to vote remotely, Representative Ralph Norman of South Carolina was among 161 Republicans who sued to block the arrangement, arguing that it “subverts” the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Collin Morikawa Wins the British Open in His First Appearance
description: The American golfer played a flawless final round at Royal St. George’s, holding off all challengers to finish at 15 under, two strokes ahead of Jordan Spieth.
content: SANDWICH, England — Louis Oosthuizen had certainly paid his dues since winning the British Open in 2010, finishing as runner-up on six occasions at major championships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli Spyware Maker Is in Spotlight Amid Reports of Wide Abuses
description: Data leaked to a consortium of news organizations suggests that several countries use Pegasus, a powerful cyberespionage tool, to spy on rights activists, dissidents and journalists.
content: TEL AVIV — A major Israeli cyber-surveillance company, NSO Group, came under heightened scrutiny Sunday after an international alliance of news outlets reported that governments used its software to target journalists, dissidents and opposition politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber
title: The Pandemic Safety Net Is Coming Apart. Now What?
description: The eviction moratorium expires at the end of the month. Unemployment enhancements after that. And then the student loan pause, food stamp provisions and more. Here’s advice on how to cope.
content: One by one, pandemic relief programs that financially supported millions of Americans are going away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: ‘If They Don’t Approve It, It’s Over’
description: A vote on Tuesday could be the final straw that pushes the Athletics out of Oakland. For a nomadic team that has moved twice before, everything old is new again.
content: The Athletics were restless at the end of their 54th season in town. The franchise had been unstable for years in its two-team market. Relocation seemed inevitable, and to stand against it, a prominent columnist wrote, would “compound a dismal mess, prolonging a state of chaos.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Where Does Weed Come From? A New Study Suggests East Asia.
description: A group of biologists and other scientists said humans began growing cannabis about 12,000 years ago not just for food, but also for hemp and, yes, probably to get high.
content: People feeling the effects of marijuana are prone to what scientists call “divergent thinking,” the process of searching for solutions to a loosely defined question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: Why Christians Must Fight Systemic Racism
description: When Christians stand up against oppression, they are not losing the plot; they are discovering an element of Christianity that has been with us since the beginning.
content: I wake up to messages on social media from other Christians calling me a racist, communist, false teacher. Such messages have become as ordinary as my cup of coffee before morning prayer. I receive them because part of my work as a Christian theologian addresses issues of systemic injustice. I never imagined such work would be controversial. Racism­ — personal and societal — still affects the lives of people of color in the United States. Part of the Christian witness involves addressing this among a host of other maladies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Michael Levenson
title: 26 People Hospitalized After Chemical Exposure at Texas Water Park
description: One person was in critical condition after the victims were exposed to bleach and sulfuric acid, which are used to maintain pH balance, the authorities said.
content: Twenty-six people were hospitalized with breathing problems or skin irritation after they were exposed to bleach and sulfuric acid on Saturday afternoon at Six Flags Hurricane Harbor Splashtown, a water park in Spring, Texas, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Indonesia is now the epicenter of the pandemic.
content: The suffering that ravaged India and Brazil has reached Southeast Asia. Indonesia, the fourth most populous nation, now has the world’s highest count of new infections, with 57,000 new cases reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Craig and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Wary and Weary, Los Angeles Largely Accepts Restored Mask Mandate
description: Los Angeles County on Sunday became the first major county to revert to requiring masks for all people indoors in public spaces.
content: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — As the sun began to burn through the morning marine layer, patrons of the Third Street Promenade in Santa Monica, Calif., were still adjusting to the new normal, which was pretty much the old normal — an order from Los Angeles County to wear masks indoors in businesses and public places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With deGrom and Lindor Ailing, the First-Place Mets Are in a Bind
description: Jacob deGrom was sent to the injured list on Sunday with forearm tightness while shortstop Francisco Lindor could miss considerable time with an oblique strain.
content: One big swing by Michael Conforto on Sunday saved the Mets from an utterly disastrous weekend in Pittsburgh. Conforto, an outfielder trudging through the worst season of his career, blasted a two-run homer in the ninth inning to lift the Mets past the Pirates, 7-6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: ‘Nobody Believed Me’: How Rape Cases Get Dropped
description: While the Me Too movement led to greater awareness about the prevalence of rape, prosecutors in New York City still struggle to prove sexual assault accusations.
content: Cammy Duong woke up in a Manhattan hotel room in July 2017 and, dazed, called a friend she was supposed to meet later that morning: “I think I was raped,” she said, crying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Jury Awards $125 Million After Walmart Fires Woman With Down Syndrome
description: Walmart said the verdict would be reduced to $300,000, which is the maximum amount allowed under federal law for compensatory and punitive damages.
content: Marlo Spaeth started working as a sales associate at a Walmart in Manitowoc, Wis., in 1999, folding towels, cleaning aisles, processing returns and greeting customers, her lawyers said. Over the next 15 years, she received several pay raises and positive performance reviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Facebook Tells Biden: ‘Facebook Is Not the Reason’ Vaccination Goal Was Missed
description: The social network and the Biden administration have engaged in an increasingly rancorous war of words over the issue of vaccine misinformation.
content: WASHINGTON — Facebook and the Biden administration engaged in an increasingly rancorous back and forth over the weekend after the administration denounced the social media giant for spreading misinformation about the Covid-19 vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Elegy for a Heartbroken Medalist
description: Japan celebrated Kokichi Tsuburaya when he won bronze in the 1964 Olympic marathon in Tokyo. But he died believing he had let his country down.
content: SUKAGAWA, Japan — More than 70,000 fans in the National Olympic Stadium — and millions more watching on television — roared as Kokichi Tsuburaya ran on to the track, one lap from securing a silver medal at the 1964 Tokyo Games. The Japanese had not won a medal in track and field, and now Tsuburaya was about to make history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: Australia’s Liz Cambage says the thought of the Olympics’ Covid bubble gave her panic attacks.
description: The basketball star explained her decision to withdraw from the Games in a series of Instagram videos.
content: After announcing that she would skip the Tokyo Olympics to protect her mental health, the Australian basketball star Liz Cambage said that she had been “at a breaking point” for a month over the prospect of entering a Covid bubble and playing in an empty arena at the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald Ayer, Danielle Brian and Norman Eisen
title: Merrick Garland Needs to Show He Knows What Jan. 6 Was Really About
description: The Justice Department should choose accountability for Mo Brooks and others over neutrality.
content: When Mo Brooks took his oath of office as a U.S. representative, he swore to support and defend the Constitution. His official duties certainly don’t include what Mr. Brooks is accused of doing in a civil lawsuit pending in Washington federal court: helping to incite a mob to storm the Capitol on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Smartphone Directions May Put Novice Hikers in Danger, Experts Say
description: From New Hampshire to Scotland, services like Google Maps can direct ill-prepared hikers onto trails that would challenge even the most experienced climbers, mountaineers said.
content: For inexperienced hikers, smartphones are a multipurpose tool: a flashlight, an emergency beacon and a GPS, all in one device. But it can be ill-advised, and possibly life-threatening, for hikers to rely solely on their phones as they head into the wilderness, experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 3 Are Shot Outside Nationals Park in Washington
description: Fans poured out of the stadium in a scene of fear and confusion and the game, against the San Diego Padres, was halted. The police said they were searching for a gray Toyota Corolla.
content: Three people were shot outside Nationals Park in Washington on Saturday night during a baseball game between the Washington Nationals and the San Diego Padres, the police said, prompting fans to pour out of the stands and players to scramble relatives to safety in a scene of fear and confusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Jordan Spieth Shows Up Strong and in Second Place at the British Open
description: The American, who has won just a single tournament since 2017, was the biggest threat to catch Collin Morikawa. But don’t you dare tell Spieth he is back.
content: Never tell Jordan Spieth that he’s back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson to Self-Isolate, Reversing Plan to Enter N.H.S. Pilot Program
description: The British prime minister and his top finance official were “pinged” by the health service’s test-and-trace app as contacts of the health minister, who has tested positive for the coronavirus.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and his top finance official, Rishi Sunak, will go into self-isolation on Sunday, only hours after Downing Street said that they would avoid a quarantine, following contact with a cabinet minister who tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Scorched, Parched and Now Uninsurable: Climate Change Hits Wine Country
description: Sunscreen on grapes. Toilet water that is treated and used for irrigation. Napa Valley winemakers are taking extreme steps in the face of climate change.
content: ST. HELENA, Calif. — Last September, a wildfire tore through one of Dario Sattui’s Napa Valley wineries, destroying millions of dollars in property and equipment, along with 9,000 cases of wine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Clean your refrigerator today. (It’ll make you feel better, promise.)
content: Good morning and I’m sorry to be bossy about this, but I think you ought to clean your refrigerator today. It won’t take long, but I promise it’ll make you feel better, and that’s true even if you woke up whistling and ready to dance, and especially if you’re blue. It’s a reset. Take everything out and evaluate it for usefulness and age. Tip the parsley scraps out of the crisper. Wipe down the surfaces so they gleam or get as close to a gleam as you can manage. Then return what remains to its right place in the fridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: Fear, and Discord, Among Asian Americans Over Attacks in San Francisco
description: A string of attacks against older people of Asian descent has led to calls for more police officers, an idea rejected by the city’s Asian American leaders.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Two grandmothers stabbed and a third punched in the face in broad daylight. An 84-year-old man fatally shoved to the ground while on his morning walk. In the past seven months, at least seven older Asian residents have been brutally attacked in San Francisco, a city with one of the largest Asian American populations and the oldest Chinatown in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: Necessary or Not, Booster Shots Are Probably Coming
description: Boosters may make it to market whether they are critical for vaccinated people or not.
content: The drugmaker Pfizer recently announced that vaccinated people are likely to need a booster shot to be effectively protected against new variants of Covid-19 and that the company would apply for Food and Drug Administration emergency use authorization for the shot. Top government health officials immediately and emphatically announced that the booster isn’t needed right now — and held firm to that position even after Pfizer’s top scientist made his case and shared preliminary data with them last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Litsky
title: Shirley Fry Irvin, Tennis Star of the ’40s and ’50s, Is Dead at 94
description: The fastest player of her day, she played down her own ability but admitted, “Billie Jean King said I was her idol.”
content: Shirley Fry Irvin, a tennis player who in the pre-Open era swept the singles and doubles titles in the four Grand Slam tournaments, died on Tuesday in Naples, Fla. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: What Is Flash Flooding, and How Can You Avoid It?
description: Eighty-eight people die on average each year in the United States as a result of sudden flooding that follows heavy rainstorms, the National Weather Service said.
content: After hours of sweltering heat, the sky darkens to a charcoal gray. Suddenly it feels as if thunderstorms and heavy rain are imminent. An alert appears on your phone or in the news ticker at the bottom of your television screen: A flash flood watch or warning has been posted for your area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Jett, Alexandra E. Petri and Matthew Futterman
title: Coco Gauff tests positive for the virus, another blow for the Tokyo Olympics.
description: Cases have now been identified within Tokyo’s Olympic Village, where thousands of athletes are staying during the Games that begin this week.
content: The teenage American tennis star Coco Gauff said Sunday that she had tested positive for the coronavirus and would not be competing in the Tokyo Olympics. Her withdrawal was the latest sign that the pandemic would disrupt the Games with the opening ceremony just days away and the virus continuing to infect athletes and others involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: As the Press Weakens, So Does Democracy
description: We are moving ever closer to a country where the corrupt can deal in the darkness with less fear of being exposed.
content: I came to The New York Times in 1992, 29 years ago this summer, as the first intern in its graphics department. I arrived in Manhattan, a little Black boy from a hick town in Louisiana, and it blew my mind.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 18, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 18, 2021.
content: A cover article this weekend about co-working spaces misspells the surname of the chief executive of The Wing. Her name is Lauren Kassan, not Lauren Kasan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC Plus Agrees on Oil Production Increase, Easing Pressure on Supplies and Prices
description: The pact clears the way for the group to pump more oil as global economies revive from pandemic lockdowns.
content: Major oil producers reached a deal on Sunday to increase production, a move that could help ease the pressure on gas prices and inflation as economies around the world recover after pandemic lockdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Climate Change, Vaccination Rates, Tokyo Olympics: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Kiang
title: Falling Back in Love With Cannes
description: After the 2020 edition was canceled, what would the return of the film festival be like? Chock-full of songs and thought-provoking movies, as it turned out.
content: CANNES, France — “May we now start?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo Prosecutors Ask to Strike Information Gained From Torture
description: The prosecutors’ use of information from a brutal interrogation had troubled Biden administration lawyers and was a source of tension with the chief prosecutor at Guantánamo Bay, who will retire soon.
content: WASHINGTON — Military prosecutors have asked to wipe from the record information gleaned from the torture of a detainee now held at Guantánamo Bay, reversing their earlier position that the information could be used in pretrial proceedings against the man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: Endorphins Fuel an Awakening in ‘Endure’
description: A solo show about a marathoner rebuilding her life takes its audience on a 5K through Central Park. Running is optional, our critic insists.
content: We stood on the grass in Central Park, just inside the Columbus Circle entrance, and put in our earbuds. Our race numbers were already pinned to our clothes, and as we waited for the whole group to assemble, we watched people walk and bike, ride and run, along the crisscross paths on a sun-dappled New York summer afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Has the Time Come to Let the Games Be Gone?
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 17, 2021.
content: “The athletes, they’re not the priority. Television is the priority.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Hal Higdon Has Trained Millions of Runners. At 90, He’s Not Slowing Down.
description: Higdon’s desire to make the sport accessible to all has made him a household name for all types of runners.
content: Hal Higdon is the 90-year-old internet king of running plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Venture to Declare
description: Stephanie Lesser shares some summertime wisdom.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the constructor Stephanie Lesser, who is making her debut today with a bit of seasonally appropriate advice! I “venture to declare” that Ms. Lesser’s pro tip is probably timely for many vacationbound crossword solvers who will no doubt see the wisdom in the four-part quip in this puzzle. (Not a spoiler! That this is a quip puzzle is signaled in the clues.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: The Ascension of Ron Klain
description: President Biden’s chief of staff worked his whole career to reach the corner office of the West Wing. He says he’s just a “staff person,” but Republicans call him “Prime Minister Klain.”
content: WASHINGTON — Ron Klain, who after a few near misses finally achieved his career-long goal of becoming the White House chief of staff, will turn 60 this summer. This is, as his boss might say, a big deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Paintings, Projections, V.R. Starry Nights: Can We Ever Know van Gogh?
description: The immersive van Gogh exhibitions make a critic reflect on her encounters with his paintings and question what it means to have an intimate connection with an artist.
content: In 2017, I took a trip to Paris, where I greedily took in as much art as I could. In one of the cavernous chambers of the ornate Musée d’Orsay was the van Gogh exhibition, his framed works (“Starry Night Over the Rhône,” “Bedroom in Arles,” “The Church at Auvers,” a number of his self-portraits) set against a brazen sapphire background rather than the usual chaste white museum walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful
title: Shooting Outside Nationals Park Injures Three People
description: Fans rushed to evacuate Nationals Park in Washington after three people were shot outside the stadium during a game between the Washington Nationals and the San Diego Padres.
content: Fans rushed to evacuate Nationals Park in Washington after three people were shot outside the stadium during a game between the Washington Nationals and the San Diego Padres.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Mystery of the $113 Million Deli’
description: It made headlines around the world: a New Jersey sandwich shop with a soaring stock price. Was it just speculation, or something stranger?
content: In a letter to his investors, David Einhorn, founder of the hedge fund Greenlight Capital, complained that the stock market was in a state of “quasi anarchy.” As an example, he cited a restaurant in rural New Jersey called Your Hometown Deli, which despite making $13,976 in revenue last year had attained a value of $113 million on the stock market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Neil Vigdor
title: Mat George, Podcast Host, Killed in Hit-and-Run at 26
description: Mr. George, the co-host of “She Rates Dogs,” was struck as he crossed a street early on Saturday morning in Los Angeles, the authorities said.
content: Mat George, the 26-year-old co-host of the podcast “She Rates Dogs” known for his humorous takes on dating, pop culture and his identity as a gay man, was struck and killed by a car in Los Angeles on Saturday in what the authorities called a hit-and-run.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How and When to Teach the Dark Truths of U.S. History
description: Readers react to a column by Ross Douthat about the value of a "patriotic education." Also: The aftermath of cancer; social media and prejudice.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
